training_organizations.name: Oklahoma DHS – Child Welfare Training
training_organizations.description: Oklahoma’s Department of Human Services partners with the University of Oklahoma to train child welfare workers. The Center for Excellence in Child Welfare at OU provides initial training for new DHS CPS specialists (including simulation training labs) and advanced courses. This ensures staff statewide learn consistent practice skills in line with Oklahoma’s Pinnacle Plan reforms and can access ongoing professional development.

training_organizations.name: Eckerd Connects (Rapid Safety Feedback)
training_organizations.description: Oklahoma DHS engaged Eckerd Connects to implement a data-driven “Rapid Safety Feedback” program in its child welfare quality assurance process:contentReference[oaicite:36]{index=36}. Through this initiative, Eckerd provided analytics that identified high-risk CPS cases (based on factors correlated with child fatalities) so supervisors could intervene. This partnership represents Oklahoma’s use of an external nonprofit’s expertise to improve child safety monitoring and decision-making in active cases.

training_organizations.name: Oklahoma CASA Association
training_organizations.description: A nonprofit entity that supports CASA programs across Oklahoma. It provides training curricula, technical assistance, and oversight for local CASA chapters. CASA (Court Appointed Special Advocate) volunteers in Oklahoma, managed by these local programs, are assigned by judges to deprived child cases and advocate for those children’s interests. With the state CASA Association’s help, volunteers are well-trained to work alongside DHS and attorneys, giving children a consistent voice in court proceedings.

policies.TribalFoster: Yes, Tribes within state provide foster care
policies.TribalReport: Yes, collaboration of Tribes with state/local public welfare agency to accept reports
policies.TribalScreen: Yes, collaboration of Tribes with state/local public welfare agency to conduct screening
policies.FatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.Def_Subtype_Abuse: Abuse includes emotional maltreatment, sexual abuse and sexual exploitation, death and near death; Physical abuse includes extreme physical punishment and shaking a child
policies.Def_Subtype_Neglect: Neglect includes (i) the failure or omission to provide any of the following: (I) adequate nurturance and affection, food, clothing, shelter, sanitation, hygiene, or appropriate education; (II) medical, dental, or behavioral health care; (III) supervision or appropriate caretakers to protect the child from harm or threatened harm of which any reasonable and prudent person responsible for the child's health, safety or welfare would be aware; or (IV) special care made necessary by the physical or mental condition of the child; (ii) the failure or omission to protect a child from exposure to any of the following: (I) the use, possession, sale, or manufacture of illegal drugs; (II) illegal activities; (III) sexual acts or materials that are not age-appropriate; or (iii) abandonment
policies.EquityStaff_Specify: Council on Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Belonging (DEIB) provides resources to staff and partners to understand how to evaluate and address systemic bias
policies.NearFatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.TribalFoster_Specify: Absentee-Shawnee Tribe of Oklahoma; Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma; Cheyenne-Arapaho Tribes of Oklahoma; Chickasaw Nation; Choctaw Nation; Citizen Potawatomi Nation; Comanche Nation; Eastern Shawnee Tribe of Oklahoma; Iowa Tribe of Oklahoma; Kaw Nation; Kialegee Tribe Town; Kickapoo Tribe of Oklahoma; Kiowa Tribe of Oklahoma; Miami Tribe of Oklahoma; Muscogee (Creek) Nation; Osage Nation; Otoe-Missouri Tribe of Oklahoma; Pawnee Nation; Ponca Tribe of Oklahoma; Quapaw Tribe of Oklahoma; Sac and Fox Nation; Seminole Nation of Oklahoma; Seneca- Cayuga Nation of Oklahoma; Tonkawa Tribe of Oklahoma; Wichita and Affiliated Tribes of Oklahoma
policies.TribalReport_Specify: Absentee-Shawnee Tribe of Oklahoma; Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma; Cheyenne-Arapaho Tribes of Oklahoma; Chickasaw Nation; Choctaw Nation; Citizen Potawatomi Nation; Comanche Nation; Eastern Shawnee Tribe of Oklahoma; Iowa Tribe of Oklahoma; Kaw Nation; Kialegee Tribe Town; Kickapoo Tribe of Oklahoma; Kiowa Tribe of Oklahoma; Miami Tribe of Oklahoma; Muscogee (Creek) Nation; Osage Nation; Otoe-Missouri Tribe of Oklahoma; Pawnee Nation; Ponca Tribe of Oklahoma; Quapaw Tribe of Oklahoma; Sac and Fox Nation; Seminole Nation of Oklahoma; Seneca- Cayuga Nation of Oklahoma; Tonkawa Tribe of Oklahoma; Wichita and Affiliated Tribes of Oklahoma
policies.TribalScreen_Specify: Absentee-Shawnee Tribe of Oklahoma; Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma; Cheyenne-Arapaho Tribes of Oklahoma; Chickasaw Nation; Choctaw Nation; Citizen Potawatomi Nation; Comanche Nation; Eastern Shawnee Tribe of Oklahoma; Iowa Tribe of Oklahoma; Kaw Nation; Kialegee Tribe Town; Kickapoo Tribe of Oklahoma; Kiowa Tribe of Oklahoma; Miami Tribe of Oklahoma; Muscogee (Creek) Nation; Osage Nation; Otoe-Missouri Tribe of Oklahoma; Pawnee Nation; Ponca Tribe of Oklahoma; Quapaw Tribe of Oklahoma; Sac and Fox Nation; Seminole Nation of Oklahoma; Seneca- Cayuga Nation of Oklahoma; Tonkawa Tribe of Oklahoma; Wichita and Affiliated Tribes of Oklahoma
policies.ConsentDecree_Specify: D.G. vs. Yarbrough (also known as D.G. vs. Henry)
policies.InvestReq_OtherSpecify: The investigation or assessment shall include an inquiry into whether the person responsible for the health, safety or welfare of the child is an active duty service member of the military or the spouse of an active duty service member
policies.ReportInfo_OtherSpecify: Indian Child Welfare Act applicability; Worker safety
policies.EquityStaff_OtherSpecify: The DEIB will provide equity support to OKDHS to determine where inequities and systemic biases may exist in each child welfare division and communication strategies to engage staff and partners to assist in the creation and implementation of processes that are equitable and inclusive to all communities
policies.DefPerp_VaryByTypeSpecify: For failure to protect, the perpetrator is a non-abusing parent or guardian; For sexual exploitation, the perpetrator is any person over 18 years of age or the person responsible for child
policies.InvestQual_TrainingSpecify: 6-week training course which includes in-class training as well as on-the-job training in the field with other child welfare specialists, mentors, and supervisors; There is a total of 8 weeks of training completion required before specialists receive a case load assignment
policies.AntiDiscrim_Who_SomeSpecify: Children engaged by the child welfare system
policies.AntiDiscrim_Who_VarySpecify: Children engaged by the child welfare system are covered for gender identity or expression, sexual orientation, ancestry, and HIV status; All children, youth, and families engaged in the child welfare system are covered for the following characteristics: age, race, disability, religion, national origin, color, sex, political beliefs or affiliations, and genetic information
policies.ScreenerQual_TrainingSpecify: 6-week training course which includes in-class training as well as on-the-job training in the field with other child welfare specialists, mentors, and supervisors; There is a total of 8 weeks of training completion required before specialists begin call intake and disposition
policies.AntiDiscrim_Staff_VarySpecify: (1) Age, race, disability, religion, national origin, ancestry, and HIV status are specified for staff from child welfare agency and contracted child welfare provider organizations; (2) Gender identity or expression and sexual orientation are specified for child welfare agency staff; (3) Color, sex, genetic information, and political opinion or affiliation are specified for staff from contracted child welfare provider organizations
policies.InvestReq_MHEvalCases_Specify: Children who exhibit a need for an immediate psychological or psychiatric evaluation
policies.InvestReq_MedEvalCases_Specify: Injuries on a child 3 years of age and younger that are unexplained or implausibly explained and do not appear to be caused by normal play or toddling; A child of any age with unexplained or implausibly explained bruises, burns, or fractures; All of a non-ambulatory child's bruises, burns, or fractures; Referrals of sexual abuse in non-verbal children whose behavior mimics adult sexual behavior, such as simulated intercourse or oral stimulation of another's genitals; Sexual abuse cases in which oral or genital skin-to-skin contact is alleged or suspected; Cases of (i) sexually transmitted infections in a prepubescent child, (ii) malnutrition and failure-to-thrive, (iii) medical neglect, or (iv) fabricated or induced illness, formerly referred to as Munchausen by Proxy Syndrome; When the caregiver admits responsibility for a child's observable injury and medical documentation is necessary to determine if there are internal or old injuries; Or all bruises or injuries to a child with a diagnosed or perceived disability who is unable to communicate effectively about the alleged abuse, neglect, or both
policies.AltResp_EligibilityMaltreatment: Only certain types of maltreatment are eligible
policies.CaseManagerQual_TrainingSpecify: Yes - Child Welfare (CW) Specialist Development Plan also known as CORE training, which provides a uniform level of competency regardless of the specialist's level of education or field of study. The development plan includes 10-14 weeks of CORE training, structured mentoring, mandatory specialized training, and intensive supervision. The Child Welfare Comprehensive Training Program (CWCTP) is a system that provides in-service training to CW specialists through standardized competency-based curricula. This system is designed to provide basic and specialized child welfare knowledge and skills and is one of several sources of job-related training. In addition, the system provides basic skills related to computerized information management necessary to support casework activities.
policies.FalseReportPenalty_OtherSpecify: Fine not to exceed $5,000 and reasonable attorney fees incurred in recovering the sanctions
policies.AltResp_Eligibility_OtherSpecify: There are less than 3 prior reports of abuse or neglect; When a report meets the abuse or neglect guidelines but does not constitute a serious and immediate safety threat to a child
policies.ExtFosterCare_Criteria_OtherSpec: Reached age 18 prior to completing GED or high school education; Did not obtain a GED or high school education and left out-of-home placement after age 18; Has specified reasons approved by the district director for the county where the youth resides; The youth is appropriate for out-of-home placement; Placement is available
policies.InvestReq_HomeVisitCases_Specify: If there is no reason to believe that there is an extreme safety risk to the child or worker; For children alleged as abused and/or neglected in all placements that are not facility-based out-of-home settings
